# List of Presidents of the United States who died in office

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![A drawing of five people, two women and three men, the rightmost of which
is shooting a gun at the man sitting next to
him](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Assassination_of_President_Lincoln.jpg/280px-
Assassination_of_President_Lincoln.jpg)](/wiki/File:Assassination_of_President_Lincoln.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Assassination_of_President_Lincoln.jpg "Enlarge")

An 1865 [Currier and Ives](/wiki/Currier_and_Ives "Currier and Ives") colored
lithograph that inaccurately depicts the [assassination of Abraham
Lincoln](/wiki/Assassination_of_Abraham_Lincoln "Assassination of Abraham
Lincoln")

During the history of the United States, eight presidents have died in
office.[1] Of those eight, four were [assassinated](/wiki/Assassination
"Assassination") and four died of natural causes.[2] In all eight cases, the
Vice President of the United States took over the office of presidency as part
of the [United States presidential line of
succession](/wiki/United_States_presidential_line_of_succession "United States
presidential line of succession").[3]

[William Henry Harrison](/wiki/William_Henry_Harrison "William Henry
Harrison") holds the record for shortest term served, holding the office of
presidency for 31 days before dying. Harrison was the first president to die
while in office when he caught [pneumonia](/wiki/Pneumonia "Pneumonia") and
died on April 4, 1841.[4] On July 9, 1850, [Zachary
Taylor](/wiki/Zachary_Taylor "Zachary Taylor") died from acute
[gastroenteritis](/wiki/Gastroenteritis "Gastroenteritis").[5] [Abraham
Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln "Abraham Lincoln") was the first [president to
be
assassinated](/wiki/List_of_United_States_presidential_assassination_attempts_and_plots
"List of United States presidential assassination attempts and plots"). He was
shot by [John Wilkes Booth](/wiki/John_Wilkes_Booth "John Wilkes Booth") on
April 14, 1865.[6] Sixteen years later, on September 19, 1881, President
[James A. Garfield](/wiki/James_A._Garfield "James A. Garfield") [was
assassinated](/wiki/Assassination_of_James_A._Garfield "Assassination of James
A. Garfield") by [Charles J. Guiteau](/wiki/Charles_J._Guiteau "Charles J.
Guiteau").[7] Nearly twenty years after that, President [William
McKinley](/wiki/William_McKinley "William McKinley") died from complications
after [being shot twice](/wiki/Assassination_of_William_McKinley
"Assassination of William McKinley") by [Leon Czolgosz](/wiki/Leon_Czolgosz
"Leon Czolgosz").[8] President [Warren G. Harding](/wiki/Warren_G._Harding
"Warren G. Harding") suffered a heart attack, and died on August 2, 1923.[9]
On April 12, 1945, [Franklin D. Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt
"Franklin D. Roosevelt") collapsed and died as a result of a [cerebral
hemorrhage](/wiki/Cerebral_hemorrhage "Cerebral hemorrhage").[10] The most
recent president to die in office was [John F. Kennedy](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy
"John F. Kennedy"), who [was
assassinated](/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy "Assassination of John F.
Kennedy") with two rifle shots on November 22, 1963, in [Dallas](/wiki/Dallas
"Dallas"), Texas.[11]

## 1841: William Henry
Harrison[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Presidents_of_the_United_States_who_died_in_office&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: 1841: William Henry Harrison")]

[![A photograph of a grey-bricked structure with green trees in the background
and foliage in the foreground all under a clear, blue
sky](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Harrison_tomb.jpg/170px-
Harrison_tomb.jpg)](/wiki/File:Harrison_tomb.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Harrison_tomb.jpg "Enlarge")

[Harrison's tomb](/wiki/William_Henry_Harrison_Tomb_State_Memorial "William
Henry Harrison Tomb State Memorial") and memorial in [North Bend,
Ohio](/wiki/North_Bend,_Ohio "North Bend, Ohio")

On March 26, 1841, [William Henry Harrison](/wiki/William_Henry_Harrison
"William Henry Harrison") became ill with a cold. According to the prevailing
medical misconception of that time, it was believed that his illness was
directly caused by the bad weather at his inauguration; however, Harrison's
illness did not arise until more than three weeks after the event. The cold
worsened, rapidly turning to [pneumonia](/wiki/Pneumonia "Pneumonia") and
[pleurisy](/wiki/Pleurisy "Pleurisy").[12] He sought to rest in the White
House, but could not find a quiet room because of the steady crowd of office
seekers. His extremely busy social schedule made any rest time scarce.[13]

Harrison's doctors tried cures, applying [opium](/wiki/Opium "Opium"), [castor
oil](/wiki/Castor_oil "Castor oil"), [leeches](/wiki/Leeches "Leeches"), and
[Virginia snakeroot](/wiki/Aristolochia_serpentaria "Aristolochia
serpentaria"). But the treatments only made Harrison worse, and he became
delirious. He died nine days after becoming ill,[14] at 12:30 am on April 4,
1841, of right lower lobe [pneumonia](/wiki/Pneumonia "Pneumonia"),
[jaundice](/wiki/Jaundice "Jaundice"), and overwhelming
[septicemia](/wiki/Septicemia "Septicemia"). He was the first United States
president to die in office. His last words were to his doctor, but assumed to
be directed at Vice President [John Tyler](/wiki/John_Tyler "John Tyler"),
"Sir, I wish you to understand the true principles of the government. I wish
them carried out. I ask nothing more." Harrison served the shortest term of
any American president: March 4 – April 4, 1841, 30 days, 12 hours, and 30
minutes.[15][16]

Harrison's funeral took place in the [Wesley
Chapel](/wiki/Wesley_Chapel_\(Cincinnati\) "Wesley Chapel \(Cincinnati\)") in
[Cincinnati](/wiki/Cincinnati "Cincinnati"), Ohio, on April 7, 1841.[17] His
original interment was in the public vault of the [Congressional
Cemetery](/wiki/Congressional_Cemetery "Congressional Cemetery") in
Washington, D.C. He was later buried in [North Bend,
Ohio](/wiki/North_Bend,_Ohio "North Bend, Ohio"). The [William Henry Harrison
Tomb State Memorial](/wiki/William_Henry_Harrison_Tomb_State_Memorial "William
Henry Harrison Tomb State Memorial") was erected in his honor.[18]

## 1850: Zachary
Taylor[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Presidents_of_the_United_States_who_died_in_office&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: 1850: Zachary Taylor")]

[![A photograph of a grey-bricked building with golden double doors under an
engraving reading "ZACHARY TAYLOR" all under a cloudy, blue
sky](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Zachary_Taylor_Grave.JPG/220px-
Zachary_Taylor_Grave.JPG)](/wiki/File:Zachary_Taylor_Grave.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Zachary_Taylor_Grave.JPG "Enlarge")

Taylor's mausoleum at the [Zachary Taylor National
Cemetery](/wiki/Zachary_Taylor_National_Cemetery "Zachary Taylor National
Cemetery") in Louisville, Kentucky

The cause of [Zachary Taylor](/wiki/Zachary_Taylor "Zachary Taylor")'s death
was fully established in 2001.[19] On July 4, 1850, Taylor was known to have
consumed copious amounts of ice water, cold milk, green apples, and cherries
after attending holiday celebrations and the laying of the cornerstone of the
[Washington Monument](/wiki/Washington_Monument "Washington Monument").[20]
That same evening, he became severely ill with an unknown digestive ailment.
Doctors used popular treatments of the time. Taylor died in the White House at
10:35 p.m. on July 9, five days after becoming ill.[21] Contemporary reports
listed the cause of death as "bilious diarrhea, or a bilious cholera".[22] He
was succeeded by Vice President [Millard Fillmore](/wiki/Millard_Fillmore
"Millard Fillmore").

Almost immediately after his death, rumors began to circulate that Taylor was
poisoned by pro-slavery Southerners, and similar theories persisted into the
twentieth century.[23] The remains were exhumed and transported to the Office
of the [Kentucky](/wiki/Kentucky "Kentucky") Chief Medical Examiner on June
17, 1991. [Neutron activation analysis](/wiki/Neutron_activation_analysis
"Neutron activation analysis") conducted at [Oak Ridge National
Laboratory](/wiki/Oak_Ridge_National_Laboratory "Oak Ridge National
Laboratory") revealed no evidence of poisoning, as [arsenic](/wiki/Arsenic
"Arsenic") levels were too low.[24][25] The analysis concluded Taylor had
contracted "[cholera morbus](/wiki/Cholera_morbus "Cholera morbus"), or [acute
gastroenteritis](/wiki/Acute_gastroenteritis "Acute gastroenteritis")", as
Washington had open sewers, and his food or drink may have been
contaminated.[26]

Taylor was interred in the Public Vault of the [Congressional
Cemetery](/wiki/Congressional_Cemetery "Congressional Cemetery") in
Washington, D.C. from July 13, 1850 to October 25, 1850. (It was built in 1835
to hold remains of notables until either the grave site could be prepared or
transportation arranged to another city.) His body was transported to the
Taylor Family plot where his parents are buried, on the old Taylor homestead
plantation known as 'Springfield' in Louisville, Kentucky.[27]

## 1865: Abraham
Lincoln[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Presidents_of_the_United_States_who_died_in_office&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: 1865: Abraham Lincoln")]

[![Image of Lincoln being shot by Booth while sitting in a theater
booth.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Lincoln_assassination_slide_c1900.png/220px-
Lincoln_assassination_slide_c1900.png)](/wiki/File:Lincoln_assassination_slide_c1900.png)

[](/wiki/File:Lincoln_assassination_slide_c1900.png "Enlarge")

Shown in the presidential booth of Ford's Theatre, from left to right, are
assassin [John Wilkes Booth](/wiki/John_Wilkes_Booth "John Wilkes Booth"),
Abraham Lincoln, [Mary Todd Lincoln](/wiki/Mary_Todd_Lincoln "Mary Todd
Lincoln"), [Clara Harris](/wiki/Clara_Harris "Clara Harris"), and [Henry
Rathbone](/wiki/Henry_Rathbone "Henry Rathbone")

Main article: [Assassination of Abraham
Lincoln](/wiki/Assassination_of_Abraham_Lincoln "Assassination of Abraham
Lincoln")

The assassination of [Abraham Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln "Abraham
Lincoln") took place on [Good Friday](/wiki/Good_Friday "Good Friday"),[28] on
April 14, 1865, as the [American Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American
Civil War") was drawing to a close. The assassination occurred five days after
the commanding [General](/wiki/General "General") of the [Army of Northern
Virginia](/wiki/Army_of_Northern_Virginia "Army of Northern Virginia"),
[Robert E. Lee](/wiki/Robert_E._Lee "Robert E. Lee"), surrendered to
[General](/wiki/General "General") [Ulysses S. Grant](/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant
"Ulysses S. Grant") and the [Army of the Potomac](/wiki/Army_of_the_Potomac
"Army of the Potomac"). Lincoln was the first American president to be
assassinated,[29] though an unsuccessful attempt had been made on [Andrew
Jackson](/wiki/Andrew_Jackson "Andrew Jackson") 30 years before in 1835.[30]

The assassination of Lincoln was planned and carried out by the well-known
stage actor [John Wilkes Booth](/wiki/John_Wilkes_Booth "John Wilkes Booth"),
a [Confederate](/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America "Confederate States of
America") sympathizer, vehement in his denunciation of Lincoln, and a strong
opponent of the [abolition](/wiki/Abolitionism_in_the_United_States
"Abolitionism in the United States") of [slavery in the United
States](/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States "Slavery in the United
States").[31] Booth and a group of co-conspirators originally plotted to
kidnap Lincoln, but later planned to kill him, [Vice
President](/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States "Vice President of the
United States") [Andrew Johnson](/wiki/Andrew_Johnson "Andrew Johnson"), and
[Secretary of State](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_State "United States
Secretary of State") [William H. Seward](/wiki/William_H._Seward "William H.
Seward") in a bid to help the Confederacy's cause.[32] (Vice President
Johnson's assailant did not carry out his part of the plan, and Johnson
succeeded Lincoln as President.)

Lincoln was shot once in the back of his head while watching the play _[Our
American Cousin](/wiki/Our_American_Cousin "Our American Cousin")_ with his
wife [Mary Todd Lincoln](/wiki/Mary_Todd_Lincoln "Mary Todd Lincoln") at
[Ford's Theatre](/wiki/Ford%27s_Theatre "Ford's Theatre") in [Washington,
D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.") at around 10:15 pm on the
night of April 14, 1865.[33] An army surgeon who happened to be at Ford's,
Doctor [Charles Leale](/wiki/Charles_Leale "Charles Leale"), assessed
Lincoln's wound as mortal.[34] The unconscious President was then carried
across the street from the theater to the [Petersen
House](/wiki/Petersen_House "Petersen House"), where he remained in a coma for
nine hours before dying the following morning at 7:22 a.m. on April
15.[35][36][37]

## 1881: James A.
Garfield[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Presidents_of_the_United_States_who_died_in_office&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: 1881: James A. Garfield")]

[![A black-and-white drawing of a crowd of people, some of whom are angry, the
two foremost of whom are bearded and wearing top
hats](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Garfield_assassination_engraving_cropped.jpg/220px-
Garfield_assassination_engraving_cropped.jpg)](/wiki/File:Garfield_assassination_engraving_cropped.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Garfield_assassination_engraving_cropped.jpg "Enlarge")

President Garfield with [James G. Blaine](/wiki/James_G._Blaine "James G.
Blaine") after being shot by [Charles J. Guiteau](/wiki/Charles_J._Guiteau
"Charles J. Guiteau")[38][39]

Main article: [Assassination of James A.
Garfield](/wiki/Assassination_of_James_A._Garfield "Assassination of James A.
Garfield")

The [assassination](/wiki/Assassination "Assassination") of [James A.
Garfield](/wiki/James_A._Garfield "James A. Garfield") took place in
[Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.") on July 2, 1881.
Garfield was shot by [Charles J. Guiteau](/wiki/Charles_J._Guiteau "Charles J.
Guiteau") at 9:30 am, less than four months into Garfield's term as the 20th
[President of the United States](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States
"President of the United States"). Garfield died eleven weeks later on
September 19, 1881. His [Vice
President](/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States "Vice President of the
United States"), [Chester A. Arthur](/wiki/Chester_A._Arthur "Chester A.
Arthur"), succeeded Garfield as President. Garfield also lived the longest
after the shooting, compared to other assassinated Presidents. Garfield was
scheduled to leave Washington on July 2, 1881 for his summer vacation.[40] On
that day, Guiteau lay in wait for the President at the [Baltimore and Potomac
Railroad](/wiki/Baltimore_and_Potomac_Railroad "Baltimore and Potomac
Railroad") station, on the southwest corner of present-day Sixth Street and
Constitution Avenue NW, [Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington,
D.C.")[41]

President Garfield came to the Sixth Street Station on his way to his [alma
mater](/wiki/Alma_mater "Alma mater"), [Williams
College](/wiki/Williams_College "Williams College"), where he was scheduled to
deliver a speech. Garfield was accompanied by two of his sons,
[James](/wiki/James_Rudolph_Garfield "James Rudolph Garfield") and
[Harry](/wiki/Harry_Augustus_Garfield "Harry Augustus Garfield"), and
[Secretary of State](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_State "United States
Secretary of State") [Blaine](/wiki/James_G._Blaine "James G. Blaine").
[Secretary of War](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_War "United States
Secretary of War") [Robert Todd Lincoln](/wiki/Robert_Todd_Lincoln "Robert
Todd Lincoln") waited at the station to see the President off.[42] Garfield
had no bodyguard or security detail; with the exception of Abraham Lincoln
during the [Civil War](/wiki/United_States_Civil_War "United States Civil
War"), early U.S. presidents never used any guards.[43]

As President Garfield entered the waiting room of the station Guiteau stepped
forward and pulled the trigger from behind at point-blank range. "My God, what
is that?" Garfield cried out, flinging up his arms. Guiteau fired again and
Garfield collapsed.[44] One bullet grazed Garfield's shoulder; the other hit
him in the back, passing the first [lumbar vertebra](/wiki/Lumbar_vertebrae
"Lumbar vertebrae") but missing the [spinal cord](/wiki/Spinal_cord "Spinal
cord") before coming to rest behind his pancreas.[45]

Garfield, conscious but in shock, was carried to an upstairs floor of the
train station.[46] One bullet remained lodged in his body, but doctors could
not find it.[47] Young Jim Garfield and James Blaine both broke down and wept.
Robert Todd Lincoln, deeply upset and thinking back to the death of his
father, said "How many hours of sorrow I have passed in this town."[47]

Garfield was carried back to the White House. Although doctors told him that
he would not survive the night, the President remained conscious and
alert.[48] The next morning his vital signs were good and doctors began to
hope for recovery.[49] A long vigil began, with Garfield's doctors issuing
regular bulletins that the American public followed closely throughout the
summer of 1881.[50][51] His condition fluctuated. Fevers came and went.
Garfield struggled to keep down solid food and spent most of the summer eating
little, and that only liquids.[52]

Garfield had been a regular visitor to the shore town of Long Branch, NJ, one
of the nation’s premier summer vacation spots until World War I. In early
September, it was decided to bring him to Elberon, a quiet beach town just to
the south of Long Branch, in hopes that the beach air would help him recover.
When they heard that the president was being brought to their town, local
citizens built more than half a mile of tracks in less than 24 hours, enabling
Garfield to be brought directly to the door of the oceanfront Franklyn
cottage, rather than being moved by carriage from the local Elberon train
station. However, Garfield died 12 days later. A granite marker on Garfield Rd
identifies the former site of the cottage, which was demolished in 1950.

Chester Arthur was at his home in New York City on the night of September 19,
when word came that Garfield had died. After first getting the news, Arthur
said "I hope—my God, I do hope it is a mistake." But confirmation by telegram
came soon after. Arthur took the presidential oath of office, administered by
a New York Supreme Court judge, then left for Long Branch to pay his respects
before going on to Washington.[53] Garfield's body was taken to Washington,
where it lay in state for two days in the Capitol Rotunda before being taken
to Cleveland, where the funeral was held on September 26.[54]

When the tracks that had been hastily built to the Franklyn cottage were later
torn up, actor Oliver Byron bought the wooden ties, and had local carpenter
William Presley build them into a small tea house, in commemoration of the
president. The red & white (originally red, white & blue) "Garfield Tea House"
still survives, resting a couple of blocks away from the site of the cottage
on the grounds of the Long Branch Historical Museum, a former Episcopal
Church. The church is nicknamed "The Church of the Presidents", as it had been
attended by, in addition to Garfield, Presidents Chester A. Arthur, Ulysses S.
Grant, Benjamin Harrison, Rutherford Hayes, William McKinley, and Woodrow
Wilson, during their own visits to Long Branch.

## 1901: William
McKinley[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Presidents_of_the_United_States_who_died_in_office&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: 1901: William McKinley")]

[![A black-and-white drawing of a crowd of people, one of whom is being
watched by all the others, all standing under a draped
banner](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/McKinleyAssassination.jpg/220px-
McKinleyAssassination.jpg)](/wiki/File:McKinleyAssassination.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:McKinleyAssassination.jpg "Enlarge")

[Leon Czolgosz](/wiki/Leon_Czolgosz "Leon Czolgosz") shoots
[President](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United
States") [McKinley](/wiki/William_McKinley "William McKinley") with a
concealed revolver. Clipping of a wash drawing by T. Dart Walker.

Main article: [Assassination of William
McKinley](/wiki/Assassination_of_William_McKinley "Assassination of William
McKinley")

[William McKinley](/wiki/William_McKinley "William McKinley") was assassinated
on September 6, 1901, inside the [Temple of Music](/wiki/Temple_of_Music
"Temple of Music") on the grounds of the [Pan-American Exposition](/wiki/Pan-
American_Exposition "Pan-American Exposition") in
[Buffalo](/wiki/Buffalo,_New_York "Buffalo, New York"), New York.
[McKinley](/wiki/William_McKinley "William McKinley") was shaking hands with
the public when he was shot by [Leon Czolgosz](/wiki/Leon_Czolgosz "Leon
Czolgosz"), an [anarchist](/wiki/Anarchism "Anarchism"). The President died
eight days later on September 14 from [gangrene](/wiki/Gangrene "Gangrene")
caused by the bullet wounds.[8]

McKinley had been [elected for a second term in
1900](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1900 "United States
presidential election, 1900").[55] He enjoyed meeting the public, and was
reluctant to accept the security available to his office.[56] The [Secretary
to the President](/wiki/Secretary_to_the_President_of_the_United_States
"Secretary to the President of the United States"), [George B.
Cortelyou](/wiki/George_B._Cortelyou "George B. Cortelyou"), feared an
[assassination](/wiki/Assassination "Assassination") attempt would take place
during a visit to the Temple of Music, and twice took it off the schedule.
McKinley restored it each time.[57]

Czolgosz had lost his job during the economic [Panic of
1893](/wiki/Panic_of_1893 "Panic of 1893") and turned to anarchism, a
political philosophy whose adherents had killed foreign leaders.[58] Regarding
McKinley as a symbol of oppression, Czolgosz felt it was his duty as an
anarchist to kill him.[59] Unable to get near McKinley during the earlier part
of the presidential visit, Czolgosz shot McKinley twice as the President
reached to shake his hand in the reception line at the temple. One bullet
grazed McKinley; the other entered his abdomen and was never found.[8]

McKinley initially appeared to be recovering, but took a turn for the worse on
September 13 as his wounds became gangrenous, and died early the next morning;
[Vice President](/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States "Vice President of
the United States") [Theodore Roosevelt](/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt "Theodore
Roosevelt") succeeded him. Roosevelt was hiking near the top of Mt. Marcy, in
New York State's Adirondack region, when a runner located him to convey the
bad news.[60] After McKinley's murder, for which Czolgosz was put to death in
the [electric chair](/wiki/Electric_chair "Electric chair"), the [United
States Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress") passed
legislation to officially charge the [Secret
Service](/wiki/United_States_Secret_Service "United States Secret Service")
with the responsibility for protecting the president.[61]

## 1923: Warren G.
Harding[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Presidents_of_the_United_States_who_died_in_office&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: 1923: Warren G. Harding")]

[![A black-and-white photograph of a procession of people in uniforms, some of
whom are riding horses, all standing in front of a white
building](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/HardingFuneral.jpg/220px-
HardingFuneral.jpg)](/wiki/File:HardingFuneral.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:HardingFuneral.jpg "Enlarge")

Funeral procession for President Harding passes by the front of the [White
House](/wiki/White_House "White House")

[Warren G. Harding](/wiki/Warren_G._Harding "Warren G. Harding") died from a
sudden heart attack in his hotel suite while visiting San Francisco at around
7:35 p.m. on August 2, 1923. His death quickly led to theories that he had
been poisoned[62] or committed suicide. Rumors of poisoning were fueled, in
part, by a book called _The Strange Death of President Harding,_ in which the
author (convicted criminal, former Ohio Gang member, and detective [Gaston
Means](/wiki/Gaston_Means "Gaston Means"), hired by Mrs. Harding to
investigate Warren Harding and his mistress) suggested that Mrs. Harding had
poisoned her husband after learning of his infidelity. Mrs. Harding's refusal
to allow an autopsy on President Harding only added to the speculation.
According to the physicians attending Harding, however, the symptoms in the
days prior to his death all pointed to [congestive heart
failure](/wiki/Congestive_heart_failure "Congestive heart failure"). Harding's
biographer, Samuel H. Adams, concluded that "Warren G. Harding died a natural
death which, in any case, could not have been long postponed".[63]

Immediately after President Harding's death, Mrs. Harding returned to
[Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C."), and briefly
stayed in the White House with the new President [Calvin
Coolidge](/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge "Calvin Coolidge") and First Lady. For a
month, former First Lady Harding gathered and destroyed by fire President
Harding's correspondence and documents, both official and unofficial. Upon her
return to [Marion](/wiki/Marion,_Ohio "Marion, Ohio"), Mrs. Harding hired a
number of secretaries to collect and burn President Harding's personal papers.
According to Mrs. Harding, she took these actions to protect her husband's
legacy. The remaining papers were held and kept from public view by the
_Harding Memorial Association_ in Marion.[64]

## 1945: Franklin D.
Roosevelt[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Presidents_of_the_United_States_who_died_in_office&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: 1945: Franklin D. Roosevelt")]

On March 29, 1945, [Franklin D. Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt
"Franklin D. Roosevelt") went to the [Little White
House](/wiki/Little_White_House "Little White House") at [Warm Springs,
Georgia](/wiki/Warm_Springs,_Georgia "Warm Springs, Georgia"), to rest before
his anticipated appearance at the founding conference of the [United
Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations"). On the afternoon of April 12,
Roosevelt said, "I have a terrific pain in the back of my head." He then
slumped forward in his chair, unconscious, and was carried into his bedroom.
The president's attending cardiologist, Dr. Howard Bruenn, diagnosed a massive
[cerebral hemorrhage](/wiki/Cerebral_hemorrhage "Cerebral hemorrhage")
(stroke).[65] At 3:35 pm that day, Roosevelt died without regaining
consciousness. As [Allen Drury](/wiki/Allen_Drury "Allen Drury") later said,
“so ended an era, and so began another.” After Roosevelt's death, an editorial
by _The New York Times_ declared, "Men will thank God on their knees a hundred
years from now that Franklin D. Roosevelt was in the White House".[66]

[![A black-and-white photograph of a wagon being drawn and accompanied by
seven white horses, some of which are being ridden by
people](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Franklin_Roosevelt_funeral_procession_1945.jpg/220px-
Franklin_Roosevelt_funeral_procession_1945.jpg)](/wiki/File:Franklin_Roosevelt_funeral_procession_1945.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Franklin_Roosevelt_funeral_procession_1945.jpg "Enlarge")

Roosevelt's horse-drawn casket proceeds down [Pennsylvania
Avenue](/wiki/Pennsylvania_Avenue_\(Washington,_D.C.\) "Pennsylvania Avenue
\(Washington, D.C.\)") during his funeral procession.

In his later years at the White House, when Roosevelt was increasingly
overworked, his daughter [Anna Roosevelt Boettiger](/wiki/Anna_E._Roosevelt
"Anna E. Roosevelt") had moved in to provide her father companionship and
support. Anna had also arranged for her father to meet with his former
mistress, the now widowed [Lucy Mercer
Rutherfurd](/wiki/Lucy_Page_Mercer_Rutherfurd "Lucy Page Mercer Rutherfurd").
A close friend of both Roosevelt and Mercer who was present, [Elizabeth
Shoumatoff](/wiki/Elizabeth_Shoumatoff "Elizabeth Shoumatoff"), rushed Mercer
away to avoid negative publicity and implications of infidelity. When Eleanor
heard about her husband's death, she was also faced with the news that Anna
had been arranging these meetings with Mercer and that Mercer had been with
Franklin when he died.[67]

On the morning of April 13, Roosevelt's body was placed in a flag-draped
coffin and loaded onto the presidential train. After a White House funeral on
April 14, Roosevelt was transported back to Hyde Park by train, guarded by
four servicemen, one each from the Army, Navy, Marines, and Coast Guard. As
was his wish, Roosevelt was buried in the Rose Garden of the [Springwood
estate](/wiki/Home_of_Franklin_D._Roosevelt_National_Historic_Site "Home of
Franklin D. Roosevelt National Historic Site"), the Roosevelt family home in
Hyde Park on April 15. Eleanor died in November 1962 and was buried next to
him.[68]

Roosevelt's death was met with shock and grief[69] across the U.S. and around
the world. His declining health had not been known to the general public.
Roosevelt had been president for more than 12 years, longer than any other
person, and had led the country through some of its greatest crises to the
impending defeat of Nazi Germany and within sight of the defeat of Japan as
well.

Less than a month after his death, on May 8, the war in Europe ended.
President [Harry S. Truman](/wiki/Harry_S._Truman "Harry S. Truman"), who
turned 61 that day, dedicated [Victory in Europe
Day](/wiki/Victory_in_Europe_Day "Victory in Europe Day") and its celebrations
to Roosevelt's memory, and kept the flags across the U.S. at half-staff for
the remainder of the 30-day mourning period. In doing so, Truman said that his
only wish was "that Franklin D. Roosevelt had lived to witness this day."[70]

## 1963: John F.
Kennedy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Presidents_of_the_United_States_who_died_in_office&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: 1963: John F. Kennedy")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/John_F._Kennedy_motorcade%2C_Dallas_crop.png/220px-
John_F._Kennedy_motorcade%2C_Dallas_crop.png)](/wiki/File:John_F._Kennedy_motorcade,_Dallas_crop.png)

[](/wiki/File:John_F._Kennedy_motorcade,_Dallas_crop.png "Enlarge")

JFK, Jackie, and the Connallys in the presidential limousine minutes before
the [assassination](/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy "Assassination of
John F. Kennedy")

Main article: [Assassination of John F.
Kennedy](/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy "Assassination of John F.
Kennedy")

[John F. Kennedy](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy "John F. Kennedy") was assassinated at
12:30 p.m. Central Standard Time (18:30 [UTC](/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time
"Coordinated Universal Time")) on Friday, November 22, 1963, in [Dealey
Plaza](/wiki/Dealey_Plaza "Dealey Plaza"), [Dallas](/wiki/Dallas "Dallas"),
Texas.[71][72] Kennedy was fatally shot while traveling with his wife
[Jacqueline](/wiki/Jacqueline_Kennedy_Onassis "Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis"),
[Texas Governor](/wiki/Governor_of_Texas "Governor of Texas") [John
Connally](/wiki/John_Connally "John Connally"), and the latter's wife
[Nellie](/wiki/Nellie_Connally "Nellie Connally"), in a Presidential
[motorcade](/wiki/Motorcade "Motorcade"). The ten-month investigation by the
[Warren Commission](/wiki/Warren_Commission "Warren Commission") of 1963–1964
concluded that President Kennedy was assassinated by [Lee Harvey
Oswald](/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald "Lee Harvey Oswald") and that Oswald had acted
entirely alone. It also concluded that [Jack Ruby](/wiki/Jack_Ruby "Jack
Ruby") acted alone when he killed Oswald in police custody. Nonetheless, polls
conducted from 1966 to 2004 found that as many as 80 percent of Americans have
suspected that there was a plot or [cover-up](/wiki/Cover-up "Cover-
up").[73][74]

Most current [John F. Kennedy assassination conspiracy
theories](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_assassination_conspiracy_theories "John F.
Kennedy assassination conspiracy theories") put forth a criminal
[conspiracy](/wiki/Conspiracy_\(crime\) "Conspiracy \(crime\)") involving
parties as varied as the [CIA](/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency "Central
Intelligence Agency"), the [Mafia](/wiki/American_Mafia "American Mafia"),
anti-Castro [Cuban exile](/wiki/Cuban_exile "Cuban exile") groups, the
[military industrial complex](/wiki/Military_industrial_complex "Military
industrial complex"), sitting [Vice
President](/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States "Vice President of the
United States") [Lyndon B. Johnson](/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson "Lyndon B.
Johnson"), [Cuban President](/wiki/President_of_Cuba "President of Cuba")
[Fidel Castro](/wiki/Fidel_Castro "Fidel Castro"),
[FBI](/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation "Federal Bureau of Investigation")
director [J. Edgar Hoover](/wiki/J._Edgar_Hoover "J. Edgar Hoover"), the
[KGB](/wiki/KGB "KGB"), or some combination of those entities.[75] In an
article published prior to the 50th anniversary of Kennedy's assassination,
author [Vincent Bugliosi](/wiki/Vincent_Bugliosi "Vincent Bugliosi") estimates
that a total of 42 groups, 82 assassins, and 214 people have been accused in
conspiracy theories challenging the "lone gunman" theory.[76]
